qas.question: What sets the Cork accent apart from other Irish accents?

answers.text: Patterns of tone and intonation often rise and fall, with the overall tone tending to be more high-pitched

plausible_answers.text: Patterns of tone and intonation often rise and fall, with the overall tone tending to be more high-pitched

qas.question: What makes other languages easier to understand?
What describes other languages spoken in Ireland?
What aspect do foreign accents not native to Cork have depending on the speaker's social class?

context: The <b4_0>Cork accent,<b4_0/> part of the Southwest dialect of Hiberno-English, displays various features which set it apart from other accents in Ireland. <a0_0><b10_0>Patterns of tone and intonation often rise and fall, with the overall tone tending to be more high-pitched<b10_0/><a0_0/> than <b5_0>other Irish accents<b5_0/>. English spoken in Cork has a number of dialect words that are <b11_0>peculiar<b11_0/> to the city and environs. Like standard <b6_0><b9_0>Hiberno-English<b9_0/><b6_0/>, some of these words originate from the Irish language, but others through other languages Cork's inhabitants encountered <a2_0>at home and abroad<a2_0/>. The Cork accent displays varying degrees of <a1_0><a3_0><b12_0>rhoticity<b12_0/><a3_0/><a1_0/>, usually depending on <b7_0><b8_0>the social-class of the speaker<b8_0/><b7_0/>.
